questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 10 days postpartum, presents with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Ultrasound reveals an ovarian cyst with evidence of torsion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common ovarian tumour in pregnancy is benign cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst)
  • M/C complication of ovarian tumours in pregnancy is torsion (M/C time of torsion-8-10 weeks or early puerperium).
  • M/C ovarian tumour to undergo torsion in pregnancy, dermoid cyst.

Management:

  • In case of complications, remove the tumour irrespective of gestational age (Rules out Options B, C and D)
  • During labour, if it leads to obstruction, do a cesarean section and simultaneously remove the tumour.
  • During puerperium, remove the tumour as early as possible.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4275863/

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks of gestation is incidentally found to have a 6 cm ovarian cyst with suspicious features on routine first-trimester ultrasound. She is asymptomatic and has no adnexal tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pregnancy, adnexal masses >5 cm with suspicious features should be monitored initially and, if persistent, surgical removal is recommended in the second trimester.

In the second trimester:

  • Lower miscarriage risk compared to the first trimester.
  • Luteal function has transitioned to placental progesterone production by 12–14 weeks, reducing the risk of pregnancy loss.

Management Of Ovarian Cyst during Pregnancy:

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4402440/

questions.text: Which of the following tumours is commonly known to increase in size during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neurofibromas (especially in Neurofibromatosis Type 1) are hormone-sensitive tumours.
  • They may increase in size and number during pregnancy
  • Schwannomas, astrocytomas, and ependymomas do not typically show such consistent pregnancy-related growth patterns. (Rules out Option A, B & C)

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7453944/

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with acute lower abdominal pain, tenderness and vomiting at 16 weeks of gestation. On evaluation, which of the following is least likely to be a differential diagnosis for acute abdomen in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cervical incompetence leads to painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss, not acute pain or peritoneal signs.

All Other options present as an acute abdomen in pregnancy and warrant surgical intervention. (Options A, B & C ruled out)

choices.text: Surgical correction of varicosities during pregnancy
Elastic compression stockings and limb elevation
Immediate referral for varicose vein stripping

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks' gestation presents with complaints of prominent, dilated veins over her legs. She is otherwise asymptomatic. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Varicose veins and vulvar varicosities during pregnancy are due to obstruction of venous return by the gravid uterus.
  • Symptomatic management with elastic compression stockings during activity and limb elevation during rest provides relief.
  • Specific interventions like surgery, sclerotherapy, or vein stripping are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be deferred until after delivery, as most varicosities resolve postpartum. (Ruled out Options A, C & D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignancy diagnosed during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among gynecologic malignancies, invasive cervical cancer is the most commonly diagnosed during pregnancy
  • Ovarian masses are commonly found during pregnancy (Corpus leuteal), but Ovarian, and vaginal malignancies are rare compared to cervical cancer. (Ruled out options A & B)
  • Endometrial cancer is extremely rare in pregnancy due to the high levels of progesterone, which have a protective effect on the endometrium. (Ruled out option C)

Key Takeaway:

Distribution Of Cancer in Pregnant Women

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3784125/#:~:text=The%20most%20common%20malignancy%20diagnosed,gestational%20age%2C%20and%20cancer%20stage

questions.text: Which of the following antimalarial drugs is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are safe and well-tolerated for malaria prophylaxis during pregnancy. (Ruled out Option A & B)
  • Atovaquone-proguanil is also approved for use in pregnant women when necessary (Ruled out Option D). However, primaquine and doxycycline are contraindicated in pregnancy.

choices.text: Arteriovenous malformation rupture, Grey baby syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following maternal and fetal complications is most likely associated with cocaine use in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cocaine use is associated with an increased risk of stroke (both ischemic and hemorrhagic) in the mother.

Cocaine crosses the placenta and can cause:

  • Congenital anomalies (cardiac, CNS)
  • Placental abruption
  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Microcephaly

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Arteriovenous malformation rupture; Grey baby syndrome (Option A):

  • AVM rupture is unrelated to cocaine; Grey baby syndrome occurs with chloramphenicol toxicity in neonates.

Cerebral venous thrombosis; Ebstein's anomaly (Option B):

  • Cerebral venous thrombosis leading to ischemic stroke can occur in the mother.
  • Ebstein's anomaly is associated with lithium use in pregnancy, not cocaine.

Haemorrhage; Hemolysis (Option D):

  • While maternal haemorrhage (e.g., placental abruption) can occur, fetal hemolysis is not a known complication of cocaine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a mechanical heart valve was anticoagulated with warfarin during her pregnancy. Her newborn was delivered at 34 weeks. Which of the following is the most likely to be present in the newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maternal use of warfarin during pregnancy can cause Fetal Warfarin Syndrome (Warfarin embryopathy) due to its ability to cross the placenta and inhibit vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors.

Key features of fetal warfarin syndrome:

  • Craniofacial anomalies:
    • Nasal hypoplasia (flat, underdeveloped nasal bridge- hallmark feature)
    • Depressed midface
  • Skeletal defects:
    • Stippled epiphyses (chondrodysplasia punctata)
    • Limb shortening (micromelia, brachydactyly)
  • Neurological defects (hydrocephalus, developmental delay)
  • Fetal/neonatal bleeding due to anticoagulation

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hyperplastic gums (Option A): Hyperplastic gums are seen with phenytoin (fetal hydantoin syndrome)

Macromelia (Option C): Macromelia (isolated enlargement of an entire extremity) is not a feature of fetal warfarin syndrome; on the contrary, micromelia or limb shortening is.

Syndactyly (Option D): Syndactyly (fused digits) is not a classic finding of warfarin exposure.

 

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3624665/

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with chronic open-angle glaucoma at 12 weeks of gestation requires adjustment of her anti-glaucoma therapy to ensure fetal safety. Which of the following drugs is the safest choice during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brimonidine is an FDA Category B drug.
  • Animal studies have shown no fetal risk, and while human studies are limited, no adverse fetal effects have been reported.
  • Considered the safest choice among the other options in pregnancy for glaucoma management.

All other (options B, C & D) are Category C drugs and hence less safe.

Key Takeaway:

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6219332/

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is considered safe for use during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Propylthiouracil is used for hyperthyroidism during pregnancy. ACE inhibitors and Losartan should be avoided during pregnancy.

Captopril (ACE inhibitor) (Option A): Causes fetal renal damage, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, limb contractures, etc..

Isotretinoin (retinoid) (Option B): Highly teratogenic and causes craniofacial anomalies

Losartan (Angiotensin II receptor blocker) (Option C): Similar to ACE inhibitors → causes fetal renal dysgenesis and oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Comprehensive emergency obstetric and newborn care (CEmONC) does not include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hysterectomy is not a routine service offered in CEmONC facilities; it is a specialised surgical procedure requiring higher-level tertiary care facilities or referral to a specialised centre.

CEmONC services include:

  • Resuscitation of obstetric and newborn emergencies.
  • Manual removal of placenta. (Ruled out Option A)
  • Blood transfusion facilities for all blood groups. (Ruled out Option B)
  • Cesarean section for complicated deliveries. (Ruled out Option C)
  • Supportive lab, imaging, PPTCT services, counselling, and ambulance system.

Reference: https://nhsrcindia.org/sites/default/files/2025-01/Revised%20CEmONC%20curriculum%202024%20-Part%201.pdf 

https://tnhsp.org/tnhsp/CEmONC-services.php

questions.text: Dexamethasone is not used for the prevention of which of the following complications in preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Role of corticosteroids (betamethasone/dexamethasone) in preterm labour:

  • Administered to the mother to enhance fetal lung maturity and prevent multiple complications in preterm neonates.
  • Proven benefits:
    • ↓ Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)- Ruled out option A
    • ↓ Intraventricular haemorrhage (IVH)- Ruled out option B
    • ↓ Necrotising enterocolitis (NEC) - Ruled out option C
    • ↓ Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)
    • ↓ Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Not effective for structural anomalies like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) since CDH is due to abnormal embryological development and not related to lung maturity.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The instrument shown is a Sim's double-bladed posterior vaginal speculum.

Features:

  • A non-self-retaining metallic speculum.
  • Has a groove in the handle to allow drainage of blood, urine, or pus.
  • Blades are unequal in breadth:
    • Narrow blade for nulliparous women.
    • Wider blade for parous women.

Uses in obstetrics:

  1. Inspect cervix/vagina for injuries post-delivery.
  2. Clean vagina following delivery.
  3. Examine local causes of APH (Cusco's preferred).
  4. Assist in Dilation & Evacuation (D&E) operations.

Other Options:

choices.text: Retraction of the bladder during Cesarean Section
Retraction of the abdominal wall for exposure of the lower uterine segment
Retraction of perineal tissues during episiotomy repair
Retraction of the bladder for suturing the uterine incision in LSCS

questions.text: The instrument shown is not used in which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The instrument shown is Doyen's Retractor (the large fan-shaped instrument in the image).

  • Retracting the abdominal wall and bladder to provide exposure of the lower uterine segment during Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS). (Ruled out options A & D)
  • It is introduced after opening the abdomen, temporarily removed during delivery of the baby, and reintroduced for toileting the peritoneal cavity. (Ruled out option B)
  • Not used for perineal procedures such as episiotomy repair

questions.text: Identify the Type of Twin Shown:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows conjoined twins fused at the pelvic region (ischium).

Ischiopagus twins are joined at the pelvis and may have separate heads and chests but share lower abdomen and pelvis structures.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560839/
